overall_summary: The reasoning demonstrates a practical approach to time-series forecasting with limited data (96 hourly points). It focuses on identifying seasonality patterns and handling data constraints, ultimately selecting a simple averaging method due to insufficient historical data for more sophisticated modeling. The solution prioritizes robustness over complexity, acknowledging challenges like missing value handling and day-of-week variations while providing a complete forecast.
key_insights: Daily seasonality is the dominant pattern when weekly data is unavailable
Averaging same-hour values across available days provides a viable baseline for short-term forecasts
Limited historical observations (4 days) restrict the use of advanced models like ETS or weekly seasonality capture
Forecast rounding must match input data precision (3 decimal places)
Day-of-week mismatches (e.g., no Monday history) necessitate simplified approaches
complexity_analysis: Moderately complex with strong emphasis on data constraints: involves seasonality identification, multi-method consideration (ETS, seasonal naive), and detailed hourly computations, but simplifies to averaging due to limited data scope.
